did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.unittitle: Alison Jolly papers, circa 1919-2014
did.physdesc: Printed materials, correspondence, diaries, publications and photographs.
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Professional papers, include diaries; correspondence; notes and notebooks; articles and reviews; prints; and photographs.

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHICAL NOTE
bioghist.p: Alison Bishop Jolly graduated from Cornell in 1958 and received a Ph.D. from Yale University in 1962. As a post-doctoral student at Yale, she pioneered in-depth field research on the behavior and ecology of lemurs in Madagascar, becoming an authority on the ring-tailed lemur. She worked as a research assistant at the New York Zoological Society, and after moving to England as a research associate at Cambridge and the University of Sussex. From 1992 to 1996, she was president of the International Primatological Society, winning its lifetime achievement award in 2010. She was also appointed an officer in the National Order of Madagascar, and in 2006, a newly-discovered mouse lemur species for named in her honor: Microcebus jollyae.

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Professional papers, include diaries; correspondence; notes and notebooks; articles and reviews; prints; and photographs.

Children's story books written by Alison Jolly and illustrated by Deborah Rossart as part of the Ako Project to involve and aid primary school teachers in Madagascar; also note cards by Deborah Rossart from the project. Also, woven fabric from Madagascar.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use:
userestrict.p: Family retains copyright; to be reviewed in 2024.
Permission to quote from or publish work based on the papers is restricted to permission of the family.

prefercite.head: Cite As:
prefercite.p: Alison Jolly Papers, #8517. Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library.

Letters to Alison at Yale
Location: Yale

scopecontent.p: Floyd year out met at Perugia summer 1959, one of circle of friends/lovers. Dick, Marie Achille - Perugia. Idilko Hayes - bosom friend met on Brindisi-Athens ferry 1951, seen at intervals since Victoria cake recipe: "To Kek" made by Greek Maid Victoria 1951-2, staple diet but needs to be cooked in local baker's oven up at the corner of Neophyte Douka.

did.unittitle: Junior year in France France

scopecontent.p: The Seacrests' probably holiday home of Kingsbury's pre WW1. AMK, uncle Ted Bishop, Penny (Eleanor) Sutherland - childhood friend, Margi Clulow, Aunt Ninky (Katherine K.K. Chase) Vatigan stamps from Easter trip to Italy 1957 with AMK, MGB, Francis and Virginia Scheetz (Cornell trustee) and Fabrizio. Ione Gyalistas - younger Baldwinite. Fabrizio and I scandalised her governess by taking her to the Lapin Agile on Montmartre. Janet Rowntree, Lisa Robinson, wife of Richard Robinson, Prof. of Oxford, long term friends of MGB and AMK (were at Cornell in wartime) Margaret Nicholl. Photos: Fabrizio Melano, Henri, Francois and Jean Lanier. Totality of my notes on "Le theme de Faust" Sorbonne course.

Menus, de Grasse
Location: Greece

scopecontent.p: My parents wanted me to experience Europe as they had known it. They saw that almost all transatlantic crossings would soon be by plane. They chose to cross first class on the slowest French line ship (10 days to Portsmouth) the de Grasse, known for superb cuisine to make up for lack of speed. I longed to be in 3rd class where young people seemed to have fun. At least I got to dance with Alec Waugh (Evelyn's brother) at the captain's dinner though he eventually reconciled on asking my age. I was 14.
